meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

価 refers to the monetary value or the price of goods in a transaction. Although it's somewhat old-fashioned and less common these days, you may still see it used in advanced phrases like 価をつける (to set a price) or 一文の価もない (not even worth a penny).

Note that あたい can also refer to a numerical value in mathematics, such as the value a variable or function takes, but it's more commonly written with the kanji 値 in this use.

Every <kanji>year</kanji>, money <kanji>enter</kanji>s the government's coffers. This is its <vocabulary>annual revenue</vocabulary>.

歳入 specifically refers to <vocabulary>annual government revenue</vocabulary>, rather than the revenue brought in by a company or an individual. It's the money that a national or local government collects in a single fiscal year, also known as <vocabulary>fiscal-year revenue</vocabulary>.
貨幣 is "<kanji>currency</kanji>" and 価値 is "<kanji>value</kanji>." This shows the <vocabulary>currency value</vocabulary>. Hopefully it's good for you when you visit Japan!
明瞭 is "<kanji>clarity</kanji>." If there is <kanji>not</kanji> any of this clarity, then you have <vocabulary>dimness</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>obscurity</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Immersed</kanji> to the point where it's <kanji>transparent</kanji>, because it's so soaked... that is total <vocabulary>permeation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>soaking</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>osmosis</vocabulary>.
If 粘る is "to be sticky" then the noun version is <vocabulary>stickiness</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>old woman</kanji> is who this is. Then, you add ちゃん for the name ender. You add お to be nicer. This person is a <vocabulary>granny</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>grandma</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>old lady</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>old woman</vocabulary>.
憎む is "to hate" - the adjective version is <vocabulary>hateful</vocabulary>.
If 憎む is "to hate" then the noun version would be <vocabulary>hatred</vocabulary>.
If 憎む means "to hate" then this adjective version is <vocabulary>hateful</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>group</kanji> of <kanji>folding fan</kanji>s, no matter how big it gets, is still a <vocabulary>fan</vocabulary>.
挿入 is "insertion" so the verb version is <vocabulary>to insert</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that this can also refer to a <vocabulary>shogi piece</vocabulary> or any other board <vocabulary>game piece</vocabulary> as well!
The <kanji>purple</kanji> <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>line</kanji> is the color spectrum that's outside purple. Those are <vocabulary>ultraviolet rays</vocabulary> (the lines are the rays).

The thing you <kanji>extract</kanji> from a <kanji>phenomenon</kanji> is an <vocabulary>abstraction</vocabulary>. Extracting abstraction out of a phenomenon may not sound like a very concrete or vivid mnemonic, but I guess that makes it an appropriate abstraction…

<kanji>Extract</kanji> a lucky ticket to <kanji>choose</kanji> the winner of the <vocabulary>lottery</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>raffle</vocabulary>! Today I extract... number 23! We've chosen a winner!

抽選 refers to <vocabulary>drawing lots</vocabulary> and randomly selecting a winner or winners from a pool of candidates or entries.

To <kanji>extract</kanji> something from an <kanji>exit</kanji> is to do an <vocabulary>extraction</vocabulary>.

抽出 is commonly used to refer to the extraction of substances, such as extracting juice, essences, or compounds from materials like chemicals or metals. Depending on the context, it could also refer to <vocabulary>extracting</vocabulary> relevant information from a dataset or text.
This looks like an adjective, but it's actually a noun. This word is the same as the kanji meaning: <vocabulary>vow</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>oath</vocabulary>).
A <kanji>vow</kanji> <kanji>promise</kanji> is the promise that you made with your <vocabulary>vow</vocabulary>. It's the <vocabulary>oath</vocabulary> you swear to keep!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>realize</kanji>, so the verb version means <vocabulary>to realize</vocabulary>. But you probably already realized that…

悟る is often used when someone understands something deeply, not just at the surface-level. It's a sudden, clear realization. So this also means <vocabulary>to attain enlightenment</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>awake</kanji> and <kanji>realize</kanji> something, you've achieved <vocabulary>mental readiness</vocabulary>. You have the <vocabulary>resolution</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>determination</vocabulary> to face any challenge now.

覚悟 refers to mentally preparing yourself to face a difficult situation or accept an unfavorable outcome. It conveys a sense of strong determination and readiness to confront risks.

<kanji>Open</kanji> up <kanji>cultivation</kanji> back on this land. It was closed before, due to it being a wasteland, but now it's time for <vocabulary>reclamation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>cultivation</vocabulary> of this land.

When you <kanji>arrest</kanji> someone, you <kanji>put</kanji> them in <vocabulary>detention</vocabulary>.

拘置 is a formal term that means <vocabulary>detaining</vocabulary> someone in custody — typically in a detention center — while they await trial or go through legal proceedings.

A <kanji>foundation</kanji> of <kanji>foundation</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>foundation</vocabulary>. It is the <vocabulary>fundamentals</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>prune</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to prune</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>to mow</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cut</vocabulary>).
Let's take the <kanji>grass</kanji> and <kanji>prune</kanji> it. This is called <vocabulary>mowing</vocabulary>.

If you <kanji>prune</kanji> and <kanji>take</kanji> from what you pruned, you're going <vocabulary>to mow</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to reap</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to harvest</vocabulary> whatever it is you're pruning.
When you are <kanji>sturdy</kanji> and <kanji>healthy</kanji> you are full of <vocabulary>vigor</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>virility</vocabulary>.

The kanji means <kanji>solely</kanji>, and this means <vocabulary>solely</vocabulary>, but also other related things like <vocabulary>only</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>merely</vocabulary>. They're all pretty close, so try to remember a few!
It's <kanji>solely</kanji> <kanji>one</kanji>. The <vocabulary>only</vocabulary> one. The <vocabulary>sole</vocabulary> one. Totally <vocabulary>unique</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>solely</kanji> <kanji>things</kanji> <kanji>theory</kanji> is the theory that only things are important. This is also known as <vocabulary>materialism</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>flower</kanji> <kanji>podium</kanji> is a podium of flowers, put up higher than the ground. This is a <vocabulary>flower bed</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>buddha</kanji> <kanji>podium</kanji> is the podium on which you put Buddha. This is a <vocabulary>Buddhist altar</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>nun</kanji> <kanji>priest</kanji> is a <vocabulary>nun</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>priestess</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>spirit</kanji> of <kanji>approximation</kanji> is the approximation of spirit. My approximation of your spirit? I think you have a <vocabulary>strong spirit</vocabulary>. I think you have <vocabulary>backbone</vocabulary>.

気概 is a formal word mostly used in writing. It refers to someone's strong spirit in the face of challenges. It conveys a sense of courage and moral strength, often associated with pride and resilience in difficult situations.
An <kanji>approximation</kanji> of the <kanji>calculation</kanji> is an <vocabulary>approximation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rough estimate</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>approximation</kanji> of <kanji>thought</kanji> is just thinking up the <vocabulary>general idea</vocabulary>. The <vocabulary>concept</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>notion</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>approximation</kanji> of what we <kanji>need</kanji> is my <vocabulary>outline</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>summary</vocabulary>.

概要 is a formal word that refers to a brief overview of key points, often used in documents, reports, or presentations.

A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>approximation</kanji> is when I say something <vocabulary>in general</vocabulary>. I'm <vocabulary>mainly</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>mostly</vocabulary> telling everything.

We're moving towards <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>approximation</kanji>. It used to be more approximations, but now it's just one, and because it's just one it's not really an approximation anymore. It's <vocabulary>unconditionally</vocabulary> set. It's set <vocabulary>as a rule</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>immersed</kanji>. Things that are immersed are described by verbs like <vocabulary>to be soaked in</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be submerged</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be flooded</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Immersed</kanji> in <kanji>water</kanji>. That sounds like <vocabulary>submersion</vocabulary>. Possibly like a <vocabulary>flood</vocabulary>, even.
Something that <kanji>invade</kanji>s and <kanji>eat</kanji>s away at something is something that causes <vocabulary>erosion</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>corrosion</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>faint</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>faint</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>faint</kanji> <kanji>water</kanji> is water that's not thick with salt. It's <vocabulary>fresh water</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>boil</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to boil something</vocabulary>. This is a transitive verb, so it's used when you put something into a pot and boil it up.

A <kanji>random</kanji> <kanji>boil</kanji> isn't all that random. It's specifically the <vocabulary>new year's dish</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mochi soup</vocabulary>, eaten on new years. Old people and children tend to die every year from this (choking on the mochi), so be  careful if you eat it! Maybe the reason it's called "random boil" is because someone decided to boil a bunch of random things (like mochi) and then it became a new years dish later on. Who knows. That information isn't even known by the ancients.
<kanji>Boil</kanji>ed <kanji>thing</kanji>s turn into <vocabulary>boiled foods</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>stewed foods</vocabulary>. You can eat anything, if it's boiled long enough.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>capsize</kanji> but the verb version is what happens when a plan or idea capsizes. It going <vocabulary>to be overturned</vocabulary>. It was a bad idea, go back, don't do it or we'll all sink!
<kanji>Cover</kanji> your <kanji>face</kanji>. Not with your hands or a puppy, but with a <vocabulary>mask</vocabulary>! Okay, I guess you could cover it with a puppy mask, but that's all you.
It <kanji>revolve</kanji>s then <kanji>capsize</kanji>s. When a ship revolves onto its back and then capsizes, this causes <vocabulary>capsizing</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>conspire</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to conspire</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to plot</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>conspir</kanji>ing I'm doing? <kanji>Nothing</kanji>... that's how much. If I don't conspire, I don't think about my actions. If I don't think, then I am just being <vocabulary>reckless</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>thoughtless</vocabulary>.
Under the <kanji>shade</kanji> people <kanji>conspire</kanji>. When people do this, <vocabulary>conspiracy</vocabulary> appears.
A <kanji>pottery</kanji> <kanji>container</kanji> is <vocabulary>pottery</vocabulary>. It's <vocabulary>ceramics</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>pottery</kanji> <kanji>art</kanji> is making pottery. That is the <vocabulary>ceramic art</vocabulary>s or simply <vocabulary>ceramics</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Isolate</kanji> and <kanji>detach</kanji>ed from everything else. This thing (or person) is in <vocabulary>isolation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>quarantine</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Isolate</kanji> this <kanji>week</kanji> from next week, and do that over and over. That way we have <vocabulary>every other week</vocabulary>.

I'd like to <kanji>isolate</kanji> this <kanji>interval of time</kanji>. Take it, make it separate, and then look at it. Now there is a <vocabulary>space</vocabulary> there. An <vocabulary>interval</vocabulary>, if you will.

If you <kanji>isolate</kanji> this <kanji>month</kanji> from next month, and then do that over and over again, you'll be looking at <vocabulary>every other month</vocabulary> isolated from the other months.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>isolate</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to isolate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to partition</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to separate</vocabulary>. You get the idea, anyways.
A <kanji>far</kanji> distance we must travel to <kanji>subjugate</kanji> our enemies. This is a long <vocabulary>expedition</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>campaign</vocabulary> to do just that!

I will <kanji>subjugate</kanji> everyone to wear the <kanji>clothes</kanji> I want them to wear. They will wear my uniform, for they will be under my <vocabulary>subjugation</vocabulary>. I will <vocabulary>conquest</vocabulary> them!
Your <kanji>highness</kanji> I am so <kanji>below</kanji> you because <vocabulary>your majesty</vocabulary> is so great and amazing!

<kanji>Vulgar</kanji> <kanji>language</kanji> isn't necessarily bad words, or something like that. It's just rougher and not as standard as standard language. It is a <vocabulary>slang</vocabulary>.

俗語 is a formal term for slang, often used in writing. If you want to talk about "slang" more casually, you'd simply say スラング.
The <kanji>peoples</kanji> who are <kanji>vulgar</kanji> aren't refined city folk. They're people with <vocabulary>folk customs</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>ethnic customs</vocabulary>.
Things that are <kanji>vulgar</kanji> are things like <vocabulary>slang</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>local manners</vocabulary>, and just plain <vocabulary>common</vocabulary> stuff.

The kanji means <kanji>mulberry</kanji>, so this means <vocabulary>mulberry</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mulberry tree</vocabulary>.

Note that the fruit of the mulberry is more commonly known as 桑の実.

A <kanji>mulberry</kanji> <kanji>field</kanji> is a <vocabulary>mulberry field</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mulberry plantation</vocabulary>. This is more like a commercial / organized mulberry growing operation, so not some random field of mulberries.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>watered</kanji>. When something is watered it becomes moist, right? That's why this verb is <vocabulary>to be moist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be moistened</vocabulary>.

潤う refers to things being well-moisturized, like skin or eyes. Think of them as being enriched with moisture. That's why the meaning also extends to financial prosperity — moisture enriches the body, and financial gain enriches your life or business. So this word also means <vocabulary>to be prosperous</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>profit</kanji>s that I'm <kanji>watered</kanji> with are pouring all over me. That's my <vocabulary>profit</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>returns</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>number</kanji> of <kanji>pearls</kanji>, put together on a string. This refers to a <vocabulary>rosary</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>prayer beads</vocabulary>. You'll see these a lot in Japan, for sale or with monks wearing them.

A <kanji>pearl</kanji> <kanji>calculation</kanji> is calculations you do with pearls. If you think about using pearls to calculate something, it's going to look a lot like using an abacus. That's why this calculation is <vocabulary>calculation with abacus</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>reality</kanji> <kanji>pearl</kanji> is a real pearl! That's just a <vocabulary>pearl</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>decline</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to decline</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>elderly</kanji> person in <kanji>decline</kanji> is someone who is old and in decline. They are experiencing <vocabulary>senility</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>senile decay</vocabulary>.
Something that <kanji>decline</kanji>s and <kanji>retreats</kanji> from decline is something that's on a <vocabulary>decline</vocabulary>. It's also <vocabulary>decay</vocabulary>.
I'd like to <kanji>infer</kanji> and <kanji>encourage</kanji> this item to you. It is my <vocabulary>recommendation</vocabulary>. It is my <vocabulary>endorsement</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Encourage</kanji> <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>money</kanji> is money that you give to a kid to encourage him to study. That comes in the form of a <vocabulary>scholarship</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>stipend</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>inferiority</kanji> has <kanji>change</kanji>d. In fact, it's getting worse and worse, changing by the minute. Each minute that goes by is another minute where you're getting worse. This is <vocabulary>deterioration</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Inferiority</kanji> is <kanji>bad</kanji>. It is <vocabulary>inferiority</vocabulary>, after all.

<kanji>Inferiority</kanji> is what I feel because I don't have an <kanji>equal</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji> with you. This is due to my <vocabulary>inferiority complex</vocabulary>, my <vocabulary>sense of inferiority </vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>inferiority</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be inferior to</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also could mean <vocabulary>perception</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hunch</vocabulary>.

Using our <kanji>intuition</kanji> we will come up with a <kanji>plan</kanji>. We'll be <vocabulary>taking into consideration</vocabulary> the information we have along with our intuition, so don't worry.
<kanji>Intuition</kanji> from my <kanji>dialect</kanji> tells me that I should <vocabulary>pardon</vocabulary> you. Give you <vocabulary>forgiveness</vocabulary>. You're lucky I speak this dialect.

I will <kanji>divide</kanji> the <kanji>intuition</kanji> up. For some reason when I say "intuition" I mean "money" because this is referring to <vocabulary>splitting the cost</vocabulary>, like when you're at a restaurant.
An <kanji>intuition</kanji> <kanji>difference</kanji> is a <vocabulary>misunderstanding</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wrong guess</vocabulary>. Sorry! My intuition was off.

When a <kanji>king</kanji> takes a <kanji>royal consort</kanji>, she becomes the <vocabulary>queen</vocabulary>.

王妃 is a word for the wife of a reigning king. She's a queen because of who she married, not because she has any power herself. The more technical term for that is <vocabulary>queen consort</vocabulary>.

The kanji means <kanji>royal consort</kanji>, so adding it to someone's name gives you their royal style: "<vocabulary>Princess</vocabulary> ______," or, in some cases, "<vocabulary>Queen</vocabulary> ______."

〜妃 essentially refers to the wife of a crown prince, emperor, or other royal family member. These days, you'll almost always see it used with princesses, like ダイアナ妃 (Princess Diana) or キャサリン妃 (Princess Catherine), but in historical contexts you'll occasionally see it used with queen consorts and empress consorts too.
恨む is "to hold a grudge." This is the noun version, which is a <vocabulary>grudge</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>resentment</vocabulary>.
If something is <kanji>pathetic</kanji> then you should try <vocabulary>to pity</vocabulary> that thing.
If 憩う is to rest, then this noun version (I know it looks like an adjective, but it's not) would be <vocabulary>rest</vocabulary>.

You know that 詐欺 is "fraud." An <kanji>expert</kanji> in fraud is someone who does this it lot, and possibly for a living. That's a <vocabulary>swindler</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>con artist</vocabulary>,  or a <vocabulary>scammer</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>red light district</kanji> (花柳) <kanji>world</kanji> of the red light district is the <vocabulary>red light district</vocabulary>, though this can refer especially to the "<vocabulary>pleasure quarters</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>world of the geisha</vocabulary>" as well.
A <kanji>rest</kanji> (休憩) <kanji>place</kanji> is a <vocabulary>rest area</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rest stop</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>confused</kanji> or <kanji>bewildered</kanji> but this is usually just used when someone starts <vocabulary>to panic</vocabulary>. They're so confused and bewildered that they try <vocabulary>to hurry</vocabulary> through things.
<kanji>Fear</kanji> mixed with <kanji>confusion</kanji> creates <vocabulary>panic</vocabulary>! You get a <vocabulary>scare</vocabulary> so bad, you're fearful and you don't know what to do.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>kick</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to kick</vocabulary>.

Giving <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>kick</kanji> is certainly an effective (if brutal) way <vocabulary>to flatly reject</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to brush aside</vocabulary> something or someone. That one kick can also be used <vocabulary>to easily beat</vocabulary> anyone.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb, so it means <vocabulary>to be cooked</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be boiled</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be done cooking</vocabulary>. Also a little cultural note — this word is used for both rice, and other foods in western Japan, while it's only used for rice in eastern Japan.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means <vocabulary>to be smashed</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be shattered</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to break</vocabulary> (for things like waves and tension!).
Remember 教授 meaning "professor"? That makes this a <kanji>semi</kanji> professor, or in other words, an <vocabulary>associate professor</vocabulary>.
